headline: WFP partners corporate bodies to provide N120m funding to Nigerian agribusiness start-ups
summarized_story:
By OBINNA EZUGWUThe World Food Programme (WFP), the food-assistance branch of United Nations committed to ending hunger, achieving food security and improving nutrition globally by 2030, has partnered corporate organisations in Nigeria to provide N120 million funding to six agribusiness start-ups, as part of its push to tackle food insecurity in the country.
The initiative is a programme of the Zero Hunger Roundtable, a public-private initiative created by the WFP with a view to bringing together key actors who can develop collective pathways to achieve zero hunger in Nigeria.
As part of the initiative, the Zero Hunger Sprint was launched to foster innovative approaches to end hunger, to be championed by Nigerian start-ups which would be funded by participating corporate bodies, including TGI Group, Heineken / Nigerian Breweries PLC, Promasidor, Tolaram Group, and Guinness Nigeria Plc.
Also speaking, Paul Howe, WFP country director in Nigeria, noted that the WFP as an organisation focused on achieving zero hunger, is relatively new to Nigeria bu has since realised that enormity or the challenge of hunger in the country.
He emphasized that if Nigeria were to successfully achieve zero hunger by 2030, it needed to have a network that is unique to it and committed to achieving the goal.

headline: Ekeigwe Harps on Importance of Self-Control in Organizations
summarized_story:
Ace Nigerian accountant, Christian Ekeigwe, has harped on the need for accountants to exercise sufficient self-control as they play their gatekeeping roles in society.
He said that after four decades of training and working in the accounting profession, he has come to the conclusion that self-control, the “skill that matters most,” is the blindside of accounting.
Dwelling on the importance of self-control, Ekeigwe pointed out that empires, companies and individuals have collapsed as a result of poor self-control, noting that in all philosophies, religions and civilizations, self-control has been shown to be a critical success factor.
“One can conclude that the majesty and affordances of accounting could not be sustained without self-control as a deliberate competence”, he added.
In particular, job profiles that are associated with oversight of high-value assets or sensitive resources should require high self-control reliability index.”Ekeigwe maintained that “self-control is the most important emerging competence for the accounting profession.

headline: 21,000 Persons Mentally Unstable In Benue – Official
summarized_story:
No fewer than 21,000 persons are suffering from mental health disorder (MH) in 23 local government areas of Benue State and currently placed on treatment.
The commissioner for health and human services, Dr Joseph Ngbea, who disclosed this to LEADERSHIP attributed the increased cases of mental health disorder in the state to invasion of Benue communities by gunmen and armed herdsmen.
He said the constant attack and displacement of farmers from their ancestral homes has left thousands of them in psychological trauma.
“There is also an efficient Drug Revolving Fund (DRF) in all the health facilities providing MH services and for now Benue State is the only state reporting the services on District Health Information System (DHIS) a national platform on which Nigeria’s data pool is collected,” he said.
While commending the Benue State government for the feat achieved so far in mental health disorder, through the sustained approval and release of budget, he said this has helped the Ministry of Health and Human Services to scale up its activities on mental health.

headline: Zenith Bank Seeks Increased Impact Investment For Africa
summarized_story:
The group managing director/chief executive of Zenith Bank, Mr. Ebenezer Onyeagwu, has called for increased impact investing in Africa for the continent to attain its full potential.
Delivering the keynote address with the theme “Leveraging Impact Investment Opportunities for Growth in Africa”, Onyeagwu described impact investing as an investment that yields optimal returns for investors, value for all stakeholders and guarantees continued sustenance and existence of humanity.
He made a case for increased impact investment in Africa, noting that investment opportunities on the continent cut across agriculture, healthcare, housing, infrastructure, electricity, and the creative sectors.
Onyeagwu also noted that as a socially responsible organisation, Zenith Bank continues to promote impact investment in Africa.
He also said that the bank leverages its in-depth knowledge of the African market to guide investors and hedge their exposures.

headline: Paris Agreement: Nigeria submits 2021 final report to UN -NigPilot
summarized_story:
Nigeria has on Friday, submitted its Nationally Determined Contribution, NDC, the final report of 2021 to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, UNFCCC.
The updated report, which was approved by President Muhammadu Buhari, replaced the interim NDC report that was submitted in May 2021.
Abubakar said: “This submitted updated NDC communicated that Nigeria has raised its ambition by including emission reduction from the waste sector as a new sector in the NDC.
“Nigeria’s has increased its conditional contribution from 45% to 47% while retaining the unconditional target of 20%.
“Hence the updated NDC has an unconditional target of 20% below business as usual by 2030 and 47% conditional contribution on international support.”

summarized_story:
Executive Secretary, Nigeria Christian Pilgrim Commission, NCPC, Rev Yakubu Pam has expressed optimism that the 2020 Pilgrimage exercise would restore peace in Nigeria.
The Prayer Congress was the first to be held in Jordan for the 2020 Pilgrimage exercise.
In his welcome address, the Executive Secretary of the Nigeria Christian Pilgrim Commission, Rev Yakubu Pam expressed his profound gratitude to the Jordanian authority.
Pam further commended the Jordanian government for opening their doors to Nigerian Pilgrims at a “perilous time like this”.

headline: Akwa United Wins 2020/2021 NPFL Title
summarized_story:
Akwa United have been crowned champions of the 2020/2021 Nigeria Professional Football League season after producing a remarkable 5-2 victory over MFM FC in Uyo on matchday 37 in Uyo.
Akwa United confirmed their intention to win the league after recorded the longest unbeaten run of 18 games.
This is the first time the Promise Keepers will be winning the NPFL title since the club was established 25 years again.
But it is the second time coach Kennedy Boboye will be winning the trophy, he also led Plateau United to win their first league title in 2017.
A seven-goal thriller and a maiden league title was quality football experience for spectators at the Godswill Akpabio Stadium who have waiting for this day since 1997.

summarized_story:

The suspect who tucked the pellets of cocaine in her underwear to beat security checks at the Airport was however picked up for search and questioning during which the wraps of the illicit drug were found on her.

headline: Two Abducted Kebbi Students Regain Freedom
summarized_story:
Two out of the abducted students of Federal Government College, Birnin Yauri in Kebbi State have regained their freedom.
The students were rescued by the police authorities in a forest of Dansadau District, Maru Local Government Area of Zamfara State.
Spokesman of the Zamfara State Police Command, SP Mohammed Shehu, confirmed this on Sunday to journalists in Gusau.
The rescue effort is coming about six weeks after gunmen suspected to be bandits stormed the school and abducted an unspecified number of students and four teachers.

headline: UNIPORT’S DVC Andrew Efemini dead before confirmation of appointment
summarized_story:
The newly appointed Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academics) of the University of Port Harcourt (UNIPORT),Andrew Efemini, has died.
Professor Efemini, whose appointment had not been confirmed, died over the weekend at the University of Port Harcourt Teaching Hospital of an unexplained illness (UPTH).
The incident was confirmed by a senior university official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Efemini was a professor of Developmental Psychology in the Department of Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, until his death.
AdvertisementHe was named DVC Academics at the 459th Senate Meeting on July 28th, but died before his new position could be ratified by the institution’s Governing Council.

headline: One dead as hoodlums, vigilante group clash in Shasha, Ibadan
summarized_story:
At least one person was killed in an altercation between hoodlums and members of the Soludero Vigilante group in Shasha area of Ibadan.
TVC News gathered that, members of the vigilante group apprehended one of the hoodlums who was suspected of being involved in a robbery case.
The incident eventually led to the death of one of the hoodlums after a clash ensued between members of both parties.
A statement by the Public Relations Officer Oyo State Police command, Adewale Osifeso confirmed the death of the victim.
Several items and property were destroyed, he claimed, while the hoodlums were on the premises.

headline: South-West Governors propose supreme courts for geopolitical zones
summarized_story:
Governors from the South-West geopolitical zone have proposed decentralization of the Supreme Court in the National Assembly’s ongoing amendments to the 1999 Constitution.
Nigeria currently has one Supreme Court, which is located in Abuja, the Federal Capital Territory, and hears all cases from the Court of Appeal.
On July 6, the South-West Governors’ Forum met behind closed doors with the South-West Caucus at the National Assembly in Abuja and presented the memo.
AdvertisementThe section presently reads, “Establishment of the Supreme Court of Nigeria: (1) There shall be a Supreme Court of Nigeria.
The Supreme Court in the geopolitical zones shall be the final court in all disputes and appeals from the Court of Appeal.

headline: Italian Jacobs Takes Surprising Gold in Olympic 100
summarized_story:
Usain Bolt would not recognize what went down on the Olympic track he used to own.
The Italian crossed the line in 9.8 seconds Sunday night, the first medal ever for the country in the 100 meters.
Pietro Mennea won the 200 in 1980 and Livio Berruti won that race at the 1960 Games in Rome.
The day’s other gold medal went to Gong Lijao of China, who bested American Raven Saunders of the United States.
Bromell ran his semifinal heat in 9.996 seconds to finish third, and said “I’m not really sure what I could’ve done better, but the race went the way the race went.”

headline: FBI Indictment: Celebrated Cop Abba Kyari Suspended By Nigeria Police
summarized_story:
Nigeria’s Police Service Commission has suspended Abba Kyari, a Deputy Commissioner of Police and Head, Intelligence Response Team (IRT) of the Nigeria Police Force.
Nigeria’s Inspector-General of Police Usman Alkali Baba had earlier recommended the immediate suspension of Kyari, pending the outcome of an ongoing internal investigations.
The IGP further noted that the suspension is also expected to create an enabling environment for the NPF Special Investigation Panel to carry out its investigations into the weighty allegations against DCP Abba Kyari without interference.
The SIP, inter alia, is to undertake a detailed review of all the allegations against DCP Abba Kyari by the US Government as contained in relevant documents that have been availed the NPF by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).
The SIP is also to obtain detailed representation of DCP Abba Kyari to all the allegations levelled against him, conduct further investigations as it deems fit, and submit recommendations to guide further actions by the Force Leadership on the matter.

headline: Turkey Declares ‘Disaster Areas’ as Wildfire Death Toll Rises
summarized_story:
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has declared parts of southern Turkey ravaged by wildfires as “disaster areas”, with the death toll from the fires rising to six after two forest workers were killed.
Fires across Turkey since Wednesday have burned down forests, encroaching on villages and tourist destinations and forcing people to evacuate.
Erdogan declared the regions affected by the forest fires “disaster areas” in a statement on Twitter.
Turkey has blamed some previous forest fires on arson or outlawed groups such as the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK).
Speaking from Antalya, Al Jazeera’s Resul Serdar said there are still active forest fires in at least 10 locations in Turkey.

headline: Chinese-Canadian Pop Star Kris Wu Detained on Suspicion of Rape
summarized_story:
Police in Beijing have detained Chinese-Canadian pop star Kris Wu on suspicion of rape.
The claim prompted widespread condemnation of Wu on Chinese social media and resulted in several luxury brands dropping deals with him.
The teenager publicised her accusations against him on social media last month and later in an interview with the internet portal NetEase.
Since her accusations, more people have spoken out online, accusing Wu’s staff of predatory behaviour such as inviting them to boozy karaoke parties.
Wu, who grew up between Vancouver and Guangzhou, has denied all allegations of assault and insisted he was innocent in multiple social media statements.

headline: How Nairobi Became a Thriving Arts Hub
summarized_story:
For many years, the cultural spotlight in Africa has seemed to be stubbornly focused on the west or south of the continent rather than East Africa.
Much of this cultural verve is centred on Kenya’s capital Nairobi, which has emerged as a creative hub.
In the two decades Eltayeb has lived in Nairobi, his artwork has been able to thrive with stunning results.
Beyond Nairobi, across East Africa, creatives are also shaping a new cultural palette, fusing ancient histories with contemporary realities.
In Mogadishu, Italian-b rn Somali architect Omar Degan is re-examining the recent histories of a city ravaged by war.
